data.text: THE MORNING OREGONIAN. THURSDAY. DECEMBER' 20. 1917. QUIZ IS TOO MUCH FOR MANY DRAFTED Questionnaires Are Still Being Returned to District Boards Full of Errors. LEGAL ADVISERS ARE BUSY Spaner, Ernest F. Woodwortb. H. B. Sandroaky. Simon Carroll. J. H. IchlHe. Keinchl Shock, Kred Bentley. Kenneth W. Notzold. Paul Androf, George I'arka, Hush W. Wilder. Earl Kuth. John B. Walgleben. E. A. Stubbs. Harold F. Johnson, carl Cook. Arthur Leslie. R. F. Crockett. Victor C. Baumover. Lee A. IJlchtftl. V.'iillam Willlame. Hoy C. .Blackmore. Fred E. Wilson. Robert ignett. Fred Alien. R. Lewis Wheeler. H. 13. Martin. John E. yjosren. Abel Waaner. B. H. Arntlt. Joseph Many Registrants Record Reasons for i:x-r..tioii and Then Sign Ex emption Waiver Error Prom ises Much Trouble Later. Whether registrants In the draft suf fer from too much advice or too little, the fjict remains that questionnaires are being returned to district exemp tion boards full of errors. One board reported but one ques tionnaire properly filled out among the many which have come back, and this one was the work of a man of foreign birth. Many registrants, whose question naires record reasons for exemption. Rally sign the exemption waiver at the hottom of the first page, the dotted line with the legend. "Sign here." seeming; to catch their eye and the caution above, not to sign unless they waive all claim to exemption, seems not to be seen at all. This error prom ises plenty of trouble, later. One Fault Quite Common. Other faulty questionnaires are ar riving1 back in that they are entirely Innocent of check marks on the first page In, the spaces which are left to fee filled In by the registrant. He is supposed to make his own classifica tion) on this page, but very few are. do in? It. It seems many are alarmed sit the idea of baring- their life history as re quired by the Government In the dTaft. They fear the Inquiry into the. details necessary to decide whether or not a roan should te called from, his home to go to war. But there Is not the slightest reason for this uneasiness. No use will be made of the InformatlonH sjiven that win be prejudicial to the Interests of the registrant in any way. Yesterday showed some Improvement in the number of questionnaires that ere coming hack to exemption boards nd they were, to some extent, better filled but than the earlier ones. These facts seem to Indicate the legal advis ory boards are doing better work and that registrants are getting the idea to a greater extent than heretofore. Instructions to Be Read Carefully. It Is emphasized by A. F. Flegel, an exemption board official, that if ad visers, as well as registrants, would read Instructions at the head of the questionnaire carefully, they would be able to return the quiz properly filled out. It Is believed that much of the trouble arises from the fact that in structions are not read with care. It is advised, further, that regis trants should consult legal advisory hoards in filling out questionnaires and not members of the exemption boards for this purpose. A noticeable Increase of business was (seen yesterday at the various board headquarters and the legal ad visers of Division 9 found it necessary to increase the working force and to move to room 601, Courthouse, from room BOO, where more room is avail able. Questionnaires were mailed yester day to the following registrants of the county: Division 1. Order Nos. 412 to 548. (Legal advisory board headquarters. SU, 21'3, 24 Falling building.) Wade. Mlchelson, Clarence MARSHAL 25 YEARS DIES Neal Bally, of Prairie City, Suc cumbs to Pneumonia. CANTON CITY, Or, Deo. 19 (Spe cial.) Neal Bally, who was a native son of Grant County, died at his home In Prairie City today, following a short Illness with pneumonia. Mr. Bally had served as City Mar shal of Prairie City for 25 years. He Is survived by his widow, one sister. of Portland, and nve arotners, XJan, Eugene, Jerry and Patrick, of Prairie City, and John . Bally, of Boise, Idaho. OLYMPIA PIONEER DEAD Robert Frost Had Been Pacific Northwest Resident 6 1 Years. OLYMPIA, Wash, Dec IS. (Special.) Funeral services were held at the Masonic Temple this afternoon for Robert Frost, who died Sunday even lng- at the age of 82. He had been a continuous resident of the Pacific Northwest for 61 years. He is aur vived by three daughters. Mrs. Charles D Garfield, of Alaska; Mrs. John Aid rich, of Spokane, and Miss Nell Frost, of Olympla. Mr. Frost was born In Tunbrldge Wells, England, In 1835. He crossed the Columbia River bar New Year's day, 1856, on the brig Susan Abigail. He lived In Portland until the Frazler Rltar. jrold. atampeO. wblch b. joined.
